prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 imaging of Abell 2744
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Continuum mapping over the deep HST/WFC3 FOV, which includes the high magnification (>10) region found via mass models (Zitrin+09; 11a/b; 12). Baseband frequecies are set to obtain 1.1mm continuum, as well as potentially catch redshifted [CII] at some redshifts between z~6-7.
Abell 2744: z=0.308, R_einstein(z=2)~30", M_einstein(z=2)=2.2e14, high-mag area u(z=8)~2.9 arcmin^2, ~30 multiply-lensed images

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe the four HFF clusters in particular, as these have/will have the best available ancillary datasetting our mosaic exposures. We opt to observe with Band 6, as it provides the best compromise of sensitivity, mapping efficiency, scheduling availability, particularly given the redshifts of our expected targets (z>2).
- SENSITIVITY: Our sensitivity is motivated by the desire to securely constrain both the turnover and fall-off of the 1.1mm number counts ~1.5-2 dex below the loosely determined ~2 mJy turnover found by Scott+12. Based on an extrapolation of the current number counts and best-fit semi-analytic simulations (e.g., Fig 2), we predict ~8 objects/arcmin^2 down to ~0.35mJy over the 2' x 2' FOV of HST/WFC3, once we correct for magnification and the smaller volume from lensing. To constrain the decline in the differential number counts, we want 6 x 0.3 dex bins (in intrinsic "de-lensed" flux) below 2 mJy containing at least ~5-10 objects each. This will be driven by the few objects at the faint end, and require ~100 objects in total, or a survey of at least 13 arcmin^2 (i.e., at least 4 clusters). To enable the above, we adopt a continuum rms of 0.0694mJy (which saves ~23min of overheads vs <0.0693 mJy) to enable ~5sigma detections above 0.35 mJy in apparent ("lensed") flux density. Based on the number counts and available Herschel SPIRE imaging, we do not expect sources brighter than ~5-10mJy within our FOV.
- IMAGING SETUP: We adopt a survey spacing of 0.8 beamwidths, which is wider than Nyquist sampling but is sufficient to generate a homogenous rms continuum map; this separation yields ~5% variations with a significant increase on covered area. For these galaxy clusters at z~0.3-0.6, ~33 contiguous pointings are required to map the u{z=2}>10 regions, but we adopt 45 pointing in order to cover the entire HST/WFC3 FOV. These regions all have extensive ancillary data to allow accurate redshifts and strong SED constraints for any ALMA detections. While ACA data could be employed to provide better sensitivity to extended emission in the gravitational arcs, we stress that the ACA is NOT required for our main science. Our desired resolution is listed as 1.4", so as to detect all but the largest structures (e.g., Hodge+13), enabling relatively robust number counts and to constrain any ``dark'' (i.e., ALMA only) sources/arcs.
- FREQUENCY SETUP: We will use FDM mode with a spectral averaging of N=16, which yields ~9 km/s spectral resolution, the same coverage as TDM mode (1.875 GHz per SPW), and a low data rate (1.4 MB/s). This allow us to optimize our continuum S/N (entire ~7.5GHz bandwidth) while still maintaining enough spectral resolution to be sensitive to strong serendipitous line emission (e.g., line widths of ~50 km/s, such as those detected from the z=4.7 [CII] detection by Carilli+13 or simulated by Vallini13). Based on the simulations of Geach+Papadopulus12, we only expect to detect CO line emission from a few (~2) objects down to the 0.35mJy continuum limit unlensed and ~10 once we apply the lensing boosts. However, we adopt a local oscillator frequency of 262.6 GHz, to attempt to minimize loses from atmospheric absorption bands, optimize number counts (via going higher up Rayleigh-Jeans tail), and target serendipitous detections of redshifted [CII] in some of our z~6-7 targets (~10 per field) and high-J lines in strongly-lensed moderate-z systems.
- CALIBRATION: No special requirements
- SCHEDULING/TIME CONSTRAINTS: No special requirements. Our proposed clusters are all observable for several months during Cycle 2.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 imaging of MACSJ0717.5+3745
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Continuum mapping over the deep HST/WFC3 FOV, which includes the high magnification (>10) region found via mass models (Zitrin+09; 11a/b; 12). Baseband frequecies are set to obtain 1.1mm continuum, as well as potentially catch redshifted [CII] at some redshifts between z~6-7.
MACS J0717.5+3745: z=0.545, R_einstein(z=2)~55", M_einstein(z=2)=7.4e14, high-mag area u(z=8)~3.5 arcmin^2, ~34 multiply-lensed images (pre-HFF)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe the four HFF clusters in particular, as these have/will have the best available ancillary datasetting our mosaic exposures. We opt to observe with Band 6, as it provides the best compromise of sensitivity, mapping efficiency, scheduling availability, particularly given the redshifts of our expected targets (z>2).
Clearly the high declination of MACSJ0717+3745 is pushing the limit for ALMA, but we have included it because it is an exceptional lensing cluster and warrants observations if at all possible. Our primary objective is to detect sources and obtain constraints on positions, so obtaining perfect UV coverage is not critical.
SENSITIVITY: Our sensitivity is motivated by the desire to securely constrain both the turnover and fall-off of the 1.1mm number counts ~1.5-2 dex below the loosely determined ~2 mJy turnover found by Scott+12. Based on an extrapolation of the current number counts and best-fit semi-analytic simulations (e.g., Fig 2), we predict ~8 objects/arcmin^2 down to ~0.35mJy over the 2' x 2' FOV of HST/WFC3, once we correct for magnification and the smaller volume from lensing. To constrain the decline in the differential number counts, we want 6 x 0.3 dex bins (in intrinsic "de-lensed" flux) below 2 mJy containing at least ~5-10 objects each. This will be driven by the few objects at the faint end, and require ~100 objects in total, or a survey of at least 13 arcmin^2 (i.e., at least 4 clusters). To enable the above, we adopt a continuum rms of 0.07203mJy (which saves ~23min of overheads vs <0.07202 mJy) to enable ~5sigma detections above 0.36 mJy in apparent ("lensed") flux density. Based on the number counts and available Herschel SPIRE imaging, we do not expect sources brighter than ~5-10mJy within our FOV.
- IMAGING SETUP: We adopt a survey spacing of 0.8 beamwidths, which is wider than Nyquist sampling but is sufficient to generate a homogenous rms continuum map; this separation yields ~5% variations with a significant increase on covered area. For these galaxy clusters at z~0.3-0.6, ~33 contiguous pointings are required to map the u{z=2}>10 regions, but we adopt 45 pointing in order to cover the entire HST/WFC3 FOV. These regions all have extensive ancillary data to allow accurate redshifts and strong SED constraints for any ALMA detections. While ACA data could be employed to provide better sensitivity to extended emission in the gravitational arcs, we stress that the ACA is NOT required for our main science. Our desired resolution is listed as 1.4", so as to detect all but the largest structures (e.g., Hodge+13), enabling relatively robust number counts and to constrain any ``dark'' (i.e., ALMA only) sources/arcs.
- FREQUENCY SETUP: We will use FDM mode with a spectral averaging of N=16, which yields ~9 km/s spectral resolution, the same coverage as TDM mode (1.875 GHz per SPW), and a low data rate (1.4 MB/s). This allow us to optimize our continuum S/N (entire ~7.5GHz bandwidth) while still maintaining enough spectral resolution to be sensitive to strong serendipitous line emission (e.g., line widths of ~50 km/s, such as those detected from the z=4.7 [CII] detection by Carilli+13 or simulated by Vallini13). Based on the simulations of Geach+Papadopulus12, we only expect to detect CO line emission from a few (~2) objects down to the 0.35mJy continuum limit unlensed and ~10 once we apply the lensing boosts. However, we adopt a local oscillator frequency of 262.6 GHz, to attempt to minimize loses from atmospheric absorption bands, optimize number counts (via going higher up Rayleigh-Jeans tail), and target serendipitous detections of redshifted [CII] in some of our z~6-7 targets (~10 per field) and high-J lines in strongly-lensed moderate-z systems.
- CALIBRATION: No special requirements
- SCHEDULING/TIME CONSTRAINTS: No special requirements. Our proposed clusters are all observable for several months during Cycle 2.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:

MACS J1149.5+2223: z=0.543, R_einstein(z=2)~27", M_einstein(z=2)=1.7e14, high-mag area u(z=8)~2.6 arcmin^2, ~30 multiply-lensed images (pre-HFF)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe the four HFF clusters in particular, as these have/will have the best available ancillary datasetting our mosaic exposures. We opt to observe with Band 6, as it provides the best compromise of sensitivity, mapping efficiency, scheduling availability, particularly given the redshifts of our expected targets (z>2).

This will be driven by the few objects at the faint end, and require ~100 objects in total, or a survey of at least 13 arcmin^2 (i.e., at least 4 clusters). To enable the above, we adopt a continuum rms of 0.0709mJy (which saves ~23min of overheads vs <0.0708 mJy) to enable ~5sigma detections above 0.35 mJy in apparent ("lensed") flux density. Based on the number counts and available Herschel SPIRE imaging, we do not expect sources brighter than ~5-10mJy within our FOV.
- IMAGING SETUP: We adopt a survey spacing of 0.8 beamwidths, which is wider than Nyquist sampling but is sufficient to generate a homogenous rms continuum map; this separation yields ~5% variations with a significant increase on covered area. For these galaxy clusters at z~0.3-0.6, ~33 contiguous pointings are required to map the u{z=2}>10 regions, but we adopt 45 pointing in order to cover the entire HST/WFC3 FOV. These regions all have extensive ancillary data to allow accurate redshifts and strong SED constraints for any ALMA detections. Our desired resolution is listed as 1.4", so as to detect all but the largest structures (e.g., Hodge+13), enabling relatively robust number counts and to constrain any ``dark'' (i.e., ALMA only) sources/arcs.
- FREQUENCY SETUP: We will use FDM mode with a spectral averaging of N=16, which yields ~9 km/s spectral resolution, the same coverage as TDM mode (1.875 GHz per SPW), and a low data rate (1.4 MB/s). This allow us to optimize our continuum S/N (entire ~7.5GHz bandwidth) while still maintaining enough spectral resolution to be sensitive to strong serendipitous line emission (e.g., line widths of ~50 km/s, such as those detected from the z=4.7 [CII] detection by Carilli+13 or simulated by Vallini13). Based on the simulations of Geach+Papadopulus12, we only expect to detect CO line emission from a few (~2) objects down to the 0.35mJy continuum limit unlensed and ~10 once we apply the lensing boosts. However, we adopt a local oscillator frequency of 262.6 GHz, to attempt to minimize loses from atmospheric absorption bands, optimize number counts (via going higher up Rayleigh-Jeans tail), and target serendipitous detections of redshifted [CII] in some of our z~6-7 targets (~10 per field) and high-J lines in strongly-lensed moderate-z systems.
- CALIBRATION: No special requirements
- SCHEDULING/TIME CONSTRAINTS: No special requirements. Our proposed clusters are all observable for several months during Cycle 2.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 imaging of MACSJ0416.1-2403
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Continuum mapping over the deep HST/WFC3 FOV, which includes the high magnification (>10) region found via mass models (Zitrin+09; 11a/b; 12). Baseband frequecies are set to obtain 1.1mm continuum, as well as potentially catch redshifted [CII] at some redshifts between z~6-7.
MACS J0416.1-2403: z=0.396, R_einstein(z=2)~26", M_einstein(z=2)=1.2e14, high-mag area u(z=2)~0.6 arcmin^2, ~70 multiply-lensed images

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe the four HFF clusters in particular, as these have/will have the best available ancillary datasetting our mosaic exposures. We opt to observe with Band 6, as it provides the best compromise of sensitivity, mapping efficiency, scheduling availability, particularly given the redshifts of our expected targets (z>2).
SENSITIVITY: Our sensitivity is motivated by the desire to securely constrain both the turnover and fall-off of the 1.1mm number counts ~1.5-2 dex below the loosely determined ~2 mJy turnover found by Scott+12. To constrain the decline in the differential number counts, we want 6 x 0.3 dex bins (in intrinsic "de-lensed" flux) below 2 mJy containing at least ~5-10 objects each. This will be driven by the few objects at the faint end, and require ~100 objects in total, or a survey of at least 13 arcmin^2 (i.e., at least 4 clusters). To enable the above, we adopt a continuum rms of 0.06924mJy (which saves ~23min of overheads vs <0.06923 mJy) to enable ~5sigma detections above 0.35 mJy in apparent ("lensed") flux density. Based on the number counts and available Herschel SPIRE imaging, we do not expect sources brighter than ~5-10mJy within our FOV.
- IMAGING SETUP: We adopt a survey spacing of 0.8 beamwidths, which is wider than Nyquist sampling but is sufficient to generate a homogenous rms continuum map; this separation yields ~5% variations with a significant increase on covered area. For these galaxy clusters at z~0.3-0.6, ~33 contiguous pointings are required to map the u{z=2}>10 regions, but we adopt 45 pointing in order to cover the entire HST/WFC3 FOV. These regions all have extensive ancillary data to allow accurate redshifts and strong SED constraints for any ALMA detections. While ACA data could be employed to provide better sensitivity to extended emission in the gravitational arcs, we stress that the ACA is NOT required for our main science. Our desired resolution is listed as 1.4", so as to detect all but the largest structures (e.g., Hodge+13), enabling relatively robust number counts and to constrain any ``dark'' (i.e., ALMA only) sources/arcs.
- FREQUENCY SETUP: We will use FDM mode with a spectral averaging of N=16, which yields ~9 km/s spectral resolution, the same coverage as TDM mode (1.875 GHz per SPW), and a low data rate (1.4 MB/s). This allow us to optimize our continuum S/N (entire ~7.5GHz bandwidth) while still maintaining enough spectral resolution to be sensitive to strong serendipitous line emission (e.g., line widths of ~50 km/s, such as those detected from the z=4.7 [CII] detection by Carilli+13 or simulated by Vallini13). Based on the simulations of Geach+Papadopulus12, we only expect to detect CO line emission from a few (~2) objects down to the 0.35mJy continuum limit unlensed and ~10 once we apply the lensing boosts. However, we adopt a local oscillator frequency of 262.6 GHz, to attempt to minimize loses from atmospheric absorption bands, optimize number counts (via going higher up Rayleigh-Jeans tail), and target serendipitous detections of redshifted [CII] in some of our z~6-7 targets (~10 per field) and high-J lines in strongly-lensed moderate-z systems.
- CALIBRATION: No special requirements
- SCHEDULING/TIME CONSTRAINTS: No special requirements. Our proposed clusters are all observable for several months during Cycle 2.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA Band 6 imaging (FWHM=1.3", 0.35mJy @5sigma) of the first 4 massive strong-lensing clusters in the HST Frontier Fields, leveraging their >5-10 magnification to study high-z galaxies over the inner ~4 arcmin^2. These clusters have a wealth of ancillary ground/space-based radio-to-X-ray imaging, 1000s of high-quality spectroscopic and photometric redshifts, and exceptional lensing-mass models. Yet these important targets lack strong submm constraints. Our observations will allow (1) a probe of the 1.1mm number counts and luminosity function ~5-10x below published estimates, (2) individual and statistical characterization of high-z star formation via SED fitting/stacking of 10s-1000s of high-z galaxies and source reconstructions, (3) dust continuum constraints on the lensing cluster galaxies and ICM, and (4) a critical benchmark for future lensing-related projects with ALMA. The proposed data will inform us about how star formation proceeded in the early universe. This proposal is a large extragalactic Chilean key project with broad community support and funding, and considerable international expertise (including many on the CLASH science team).
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
